oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Homes on the riverfront
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two old plantation houses sit back on a bluff overlooking the river. It appears that a stone wall surrounds the house at center. A large feature of the picture is the prominent horizontal striation of the bluff.

The most notable features of the house at center include the frilly porch and the columns. The facade speaks Victorian, but it was probably a modernization of an antebellum structure in a style such as Federal or Greek Revival. Riverfront property was especially valuable to commerce since trails and ramps to the water provided a means to get cotton and tobacco to market.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houses; Dwellings; Rivers; Waterfronts; Stone walls
